Award.AwardTitle: Weak and Electromagnetic Radiative Corrections in Atomic Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The science to be carried out with support from this award is in the field of bound state quantum field theory. The present understanding of atoms is that they consist of negative electrons bound to positively charged nuclei, with the simplest atom being hydrogen, an electron bound to the proton. The underlying theory of hydrogen and more complicated atoms and molecules is called quantum electrodynamics (QED), a field of expertise of the principal investigator. Small but important shifts in atomic energy levels coming from this field theory and other field theories modeled on it,collectively called the Standard Model, will be calculated, with an emphasis on effects from part of the Standard Model to do with a possible electric dipole moment of the electron. This latter violates an incompletely understood symmetry called time reversal symmetry, which is involved in understanding why the universe is made of more matter than antimatter.

The training of at least one graduate student in this field is the first 'broader impact' component of this grant. Secondly, an interdisciplinary aspect is present. The above mentioned proton is also a bound state, consisting of three quarks, but is generally treated with techniques very different from those used in atoms, for example lattice QCD. Building on previous work of the author in collaboration with Dr. Peter Mohr of NIST, atomic techniques will be applied to the calculation of various properties of the proton. Of particular interest is a current controversy about the size of this particle, and it is hoped that use of atomic techniques on the proton will lead to a resolution of this controversy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantum field theory is a branch of theoretical physics that combines quantum mechanics and relativity that has proven to be a very powerful way of describing nature at a fundamental level. When electromagnetism is the dominant force present, the theory (QED, standing for Quantum Electrodynamics) allows extremely precise predictions that agree with experiment to very high accuracy. It is challenging, however, to apply QED to the bound state problem, that is, the case when charged particles are bound into atoms such as the sodium atom, consisting of eleven electrons and a nucleus. The research carried out in this grant involves carrying out calculations on atoms and ions. Some of the research attempts to make predictions of high precision to test our understanding of QED, and some involves using atoms as probes of the other interactions in nature, the weak and strong interactions. A relatively poorly understood part of the weak interactions involves the violation of time reversal symmetry, which should allow the electron to have a small electric dipole moment. Such a moment has not been seen, but experiments in atoms and molecules are being vigorously pursued, and the associated theory has been part of the research. Finally, while the basic picture of particles such as the proton and neutron is that they consist of three quarks bound together, the techniques usually used to calculate their properties are very different from those used to describe electrons bound in atoms. Reseach has been carried out to extend the atomic methods to the proton and neutron, with emphasis on attempting to resolve a discrepancy involving the size of the proton.
